[{"name":"read_files","result":"{\"src/renderer/screens/AllAgentsView.tsx\":\"import { useMemo } from 'react';\\nimport { useAgents } from '../contexts/AgentsContext';\\nimport ModelChip from '../components/agents/ModelChip';\\nimport ProjectChip from '../components/agents/ProjectChip';\\n\\nfunction formatUSD(n?: number) {\\n if (n == null || !isFinite(n)) return '\\\\u2014';\\n return `$${n.toFixed(4)}`;\\n}\\n\\nfunction formatInteger(n?: number) {\\n if (n == null || !isFinite(n)) return '\\\\u2014';\\n return Math.round(n).toLocaleString();\\n}\\n\\nfunction formatDuration(ms?: number) {\\n if (ms == null || !isFinite(ms) || ms < 0) return '\\\\u2014';\\n if (ms < 1000) return `${Math.round(ms)}ms`;\\n const s = Math.floor(ms / 1000);\\n const hrs = Math.floor(s / 3600);\\n const mins = Math.floor((s % 3600) / 60);\\n const secs = s % 60;\\n const parts: string[] = [];\\n if (hrs) parts.push(`${hrs}h`);\\n if (mins) parts.push(`${mins}m`);\\n parts.push(`${secs}s`);\\n return parts.join(' ');\\n}\\n\\nexport default function AllAgentsView() {\\n const { runsHistory } = useAgents();\\n\\n type ModelKey = string; // provider::model\\n type ProjectKey = string; // projectId\\n\\n const stats = useMemo(() => {\\n const allRuns = runsHistory.slice();\\n\\n const runCalcs = allRuns.map((r) => {\\n const prompt = r.conversations.flatMap((c) => c.messages).map((m) => m.promptTokens ?? 0).reduce((a, b) => a + b, 0);\\n const completion = r.conversations.flatMap((c) => c.messages).map((m) => m.completionTokens ?? 0).reduce((a, b) => a + b, 0);\\n const costUSD = (r.price.inputPerMTokensUSD * prompt) / 1_000_000 + (r.price.outputPerMTokensUSD * completion) / 1_000_000;\\n const startedMs = r.startedAt ? new Date(r.startedAt).getTime() : NaN;\\n const finishedMs = r.finishedAt ? new Date(r.finishedAt).getTime() : (r.updatedAt ? new Date(r.updatedAt).getTime() : Date.now());\\n const durationMs = isFinite(startedMs) && isFinite(finishedMs) ? Math.max(0, finishedMs - startedMs) : undefined;\\n const completedFeatures = r.conversations.filter((c) => c.state === 'completed').length;\\n const totalFeatures = r.conversations.length;\\n const modelKey: ModelKey = `${r.llmConfig.provider || 'unknown'}::${r.llmConfig.model || 'unknown'}`;\\n const projectKey: ProjectKey = r.projectId || 'unknown';\\n const rating = r.rating?.score; // 0 or 1\\n return { r, prompt, completion, costUSD, durationMs, completedFeatures, totalFeatures, modelKey, projectKey, rating };\\n });\\n\\n // Overall totals\\n const totalRuns = runCalcs.length;\\n const active = runsHistory.filter((r) => r.state === 'running').length;\\n const totalPrompt = runCalcs.reduce((a, b) => a + (b.prompt || 0), 0);\\n const totalCompletion = runCalcs.reduce((a, b) => a + (b.completion || 0), 0);\\n const totalCost = runCalcs.reduce((a, b) => a + (b.costUSD || 0), 0);\\n\\n // Group by model\\n const byModel = new Map>();\\n function makeModelAgg() {\\n return {\\n runs: 0,\\n costSum: 0,\\n tokensSum: 0,\\n durationSumMs: 0, // total duration across runs (for reference)\\n completedFeaturesSum: 0,\\n ratingSum: 0,\\n ratingCount: 0,\\n any: null as null | (typeof runCalcs[number]),\\n };\\n }\\n for (const rc of runCalcs) {\\n const m = byModel.get(rc.modelKey) || makeModelAgg();\\n m.runs += 1;\\n m.costSum += rc.costUSD || 0;\\n m.tokensSum += (rc.prompt || 0) + (rc.completion || 0);\\n if (rc.durationMs != null) m.durationSumMs += rc.durationMs;\\n if (rc.completedFeatures > 0 && rc.durationMs != null) {\\n // For per-feature average, aggregate as total duration over total completed features\\n m.completedFeaturesSum += rc.completedFeatures;\\n }\\n if (rc.rating != null) {\\n m.ratingSum += rc.rating;\\n m.ratingCount += 1;\\n }\\n if (!m.any) m.any = rc;\\n byModel.set(rc.modelKey, m);\\n }\\n\\n const modelsList = Array.from(byModel.entries()).map(([key, m]) => {\\n const [provider, model] = key.split('::');\\n const avgCost = m.runs ? m.costSum / m.runs : undefined;\\n const avgTokens = m.runs ? m.tokensSum / m.runs : undefined;\\n const avgRating = m.ratingCount ? m.ratingSum / m.ratingCount : undefined;\\n const avgPerFeatureDurationMs = m.completedFeaturesSum > 0 ? m.durationSumMs / m.completedFeaturesSum : undefined;\\n return { key, provider, model, runs: m.runs, avgCost, avgTokens, avgRating, avgPerFeatureDurationMs };\\n });\\n\\n // Extremes overall (consider only defined metrics)\\n const cheapestModel = modelsList.filter(m => m.avgCost != null).sort((a, b) => (a.avgCost! - b.avgCost!))[0];\\n const mostExpensiveModel = modelsList.filter(m => m.avgCost != null).sort((a, b) => (b.avgCost! - a.avgCost!))[0];\\n const fastestModel = modelsList.filter(m => m.avgPerFeatureDurationMs != null).sort((a, b) => (a.avgPerFeatureDurationMs! - b.avgPerFeatureDurationMs!))[0];\\n const slowestModel = modelsList.filter(m => m.avgPerFeatureDurationMs != null).sort((a, b) => (b.avgPerFeatureDurationMs! - a.avgPerFeatureDurationMs!))[0];\\n const highestRatedModel = modelsList.filter(m => m.avgRating != null).sort((a, b) => (b.avgRating! - a.avgRating!))[0];\\n const lowestRatedModel = modelsList.filter(m => m.avgRating != null).sort((a, b) => (a.avgRating! - b.avgRating!))[0];\\n\\n // Group by project, with same per-model stats within each project\\n type ProjectAgg = {\\n key: ProjectKey;\\n runs: number;\\n costSum: number;\\n byModel: Map>;\\n };\\n const byProject = new Map();\\n for (const rc of runCalcs) {\\n const p = byProject.get(rc.projectKey) || { key: rc.projectKey, runs: 0, costSum: 0, byModel: new Map() };\\n p.runs += 1;\\n p.costSum += rc.costUSD || 0;\\n const pm = p.byModel.get(rc.modelKey) || makeModelAgg();\\n pm.runs += 1;\\n pm.costSum += rc.costUSD || 0;\\n pm.tokensSum += (rc.prompt || 0) + (rc.completion || 0);\\n if (rc.durationMs != null) pm.durationSumMs += rc.durationMs;\\n if (rc.completedFeatures > 0 && rc.durationMs != null) {\\n pm.completedFeaturesSum += rc.completedFeatures;\\n }\\n if (rc.rating != null) {\\n pm.ratingSum += rc.rating;\\n pm.ratingCount += 1;\\n }\\n if (!pm.any) pm.any = rc;\\n p.byModel.set(rc.modelKey, pm);\\n byProject.set(rc.projectKey, p);\\n }\\n\\n const projectsList = Array.from(byProject.values()).map((p) => {\\n const models = Array.from(p.byModel.entries()).map(([key, m]) => {\\n const [provider, model] = key.split('::');\\n const avgCost = m.runs ? m.costSum / m.runs : undefined;\\n const avgTokens = m.runs ? m.tokensSum / m.runs : undefined;\\n const avgRating = m.ratingCount ? m.ratingSum / m.ratingCount : undefined;\\n const avgPerFeatureDurationMs = m.completedFeaturesSum > 0 ? m.durationSumMs / m.completedFeaturesSum : undefined;\\n return { key, provider, model, runs: m.runs, avgCost, avgTokens, avgRating, avgPerFeatureDurationMs };\\n });\\n const cheapest = models.filter(m => m.avgCost != null).sort((a, b) => (a.avgCost! - b.avgCost!))[0];\\n const mostExpensive = models.filter(m => m.avgCost != null).sort((a, b) => (b.avgCost! - a.avgCost!))[0];\\n const fastest = models.filter(m => m.avgPerFeatureDurationMs != null).sort((a, b) => (a.avgPerFeatureDurationMs! - b.avgPerFeatureDurationMs!))[0];\\n const slowest = models.filter(m => m.avgPerFeatureDurationMs != null).sort((a, b) => (b.avgPerFeatureDurationMs! - a.avgPerFeatureDurationMs!))[0];\\n const highestRated = models.filter(m => m.avgRating != null).sort((a, b) => (b.avgRating! - a.avgRating!))[0];\\n const lowestRated = models.filter(m => m.avgRating != null).sort((a, b) => (a.avgRating! - b.avgRating!))[0];\\n\\n return {\\n projectId: p.key,\\n runs: p.runs,\\n costSum: p.costSum,\\n avgCost: p.runs ? p.costSum / p.runs : undefined,\\n models,\\n cheapest,\\n mostExpensive,\\n fastest,\\n slowest,\\n highestRated,\\n lowestRated,\\n };\\n }).sort((a, b) => a.projectId.localeCompare(b.projectId));\\n\\n return {\\n kpis: {\\n totalRuns,\\n active,\\n totals: { prompt: totalPrompt, completion: totalCompletion },\\n cost: totalCost,\\n },\\n modelsList,\\n extremes: { cheapestModel, mostExpensiveModel, fastestModel, slowestModel, highestRatedModel, lowestRatedModel },\\n projectsList,\\n };\\n }, [runsHistory]);\\n\\n return (\\n
\\n

Do not list individual files.\\n- Keep bullets short (one sentence) and avoid \\\"New:\\\" or historical notes.\\n- When adding/removing a major directory or moving a subsystem, update a single bullet here.\\n- Prefer linking or pointing to deeper docs (README/OVERVIEW) rather than describing internals here.\\n- Never document build related artifacts.\\n\\nTop-Level Layout\\n- docs/: Project-wide documentation and specs; single source of truth for protocols and workflows.\\n- src/: Application source (Electron app: main, preload, renderer, and tooling).\\n - live-data/: Main process live data service and types for live data services.\\n - providers/: Pluggable provider implementations (e.g., agent-prices bridge, generic fetch-json).\\n - registry.js: Provider registry to map service ids to providers.\\n - store.js: Persistence for service configs and cached snapshots by service id.\\n - types.js: Shared types and helpers (freshness policy, normalization, freshness computation).\\n - renderer/: React UI (components, screens, hooks, services, navigation, preview runtime).\\n - components/agents/: Agent-specific UI (status chips, run bullets, model selectors, project/cost/token chips).\\n - services/: Renderer-side services (e.g., pricingService for LLM price lookup via IPC).\\n - hooks/useShortcuts: Keyboard shortcuts provider; respects user-selected modifier and avoids interfering with text input.\\n - settings/: AppSettings React context provider used app-wide (singleton).\\n - tools/: Developer and agent tooling (preview analyzer, factory integration, helpers).\\n - main.js: Electron main process entry.\\n - preload.js: Safe IPC surface exposed to the renderer (exposes live data API).\\n- packages/: Local monorepo packages.\\n - factory-ts/: Agent orchestration library (orchestrator, pricing, history, completion, git integration).\\n- scripts/: Project automation scripts and CLIs.\\n- Root config files: package.json, tsconfig.json, tailwind/postcss configs, vite configs, forge config, .env.\\n\\nWhere to Learn More\\n- Agents and roles: packages/factory-ts/docs (AGENT_*.md).\\n- Factory TS overview and APIs: packages/factory-ts (see README/OVERVIEW files in that package).\\n- Preview system: see src/renderer/preview and related docs in docs/ (preview usage and analyzer).\\n- IPC and factory integration: src/tools/factory (renderer bridge and main process handlers).\\n\\nConventions (brief)\\n- Keep cross-cutting documentation in docs/; place domain-specific or area-specific READMEs next to the code they describe.\\n- Use descriptive directory names and keep responsibilities separated by area (renderer vs main vs tools vs packages).\\n\\nEnvironment & Credentials\\n- .env at the repo root is used for local development (e.g., credentials consumed by tooling and factory-ts).\\n\\nNotes\\n- If you are unsure whether something belongs here, it probably belongs in a local README under its directory, with this file providing only a one-line pointer to that area.\\n\"}"},{"name":"write_file","result":"File securely written to: src/renderer/screens/AllAgentsView.tsx"},{"name":"finish_feature","result":"Feature af06b354-ef07-4764-8be3-2f731e9aad33 finished by developer and changes committed."}]

# Developer Agent Steps Execution

You are the Developer Agent. You will be assigned a single feature to implement. Your goal is to complete it by following these steps precisely.

## Workflow

1.  **Analyze the Feature**: Read the feature's title, description and rejection (if provided) to understand its goal.
2.  **Consult the File Structure**: Use the provided `docs/FILE_ORGANISATION.md` to understand the project context.
3.  **Implement**: Write or modify files to meet the feature's acceptance criteria. Use the `write_file`, `rename_file`, `delete_file`, `list_files` and `search_files` tools for all file operations.
4.  **Complete the Feature**: When the feature is complete, you **MUST** call the `finish_feature` tool. This is your final step for a successful implementation.
5.  **Handle Blockers**: If you cannot proceed, you **MUST** use `block_feature` to explain the reason for being stuck - this signals that you are blocked and ready for a new assignment.

## Notes

For context on the overall project structure, including how tasks and features are organized, refer to `docs/FILE_ORGANISATION.md`. You should always update this file with new major directory changes.
#CURRENT TASK (ID: f67e8921-b197-40c9-9154-e95db8f27deb)
##TITLE:
UI Improvements
##DESCRIPTION:
Various UI improvements to the app


#ASSIGNED FEATURE: Apply formatter on save (ID: 60237404-0b90-4663-9ed3-de9db2d77354)
##DESCRIPTION: When using VSCode and saving a file the project needs to auto apply a formatter so that all code is always in the same style.
We also need to have a script under /scripts that can be run on all files to make sure they have the format applied.




#ACCEPTANCE CRITERIA:

#TOOL SIGNATURES:
- read_files(paths: list[str]) -> list[str] - Read the content of one or more files at the given relative paths. Returns an array of strings (one per file).
- search_files(query: str, path: str = '.') -> list[str] - Search for files by name or textual content under the given path. Returns matching relative paths. The query input must be a space separated list of keywords
- block_feature(reason: str) - Stop work on the current feature and report why you are blocked (e.g., missing context, unclear requirements).
- finish_feature() - Mark the current feature as complete and end the run. Use only when the work fully meets the acceptance criteria.
- list_files(path: str) - List files and directories at a relative path from the project root.
- write_file(filename: str, content: str) - Create or overwrite a file with the given content. Always use this to write code or docs.
- rename_file(filename: str, new_filename: str) - Rename or move a file from one path to another.
- delete_file(filename: str) - Delete a file. Use with caution and only when necessary.
- run_test() -> str - Run the test for the current feature and return the output. Use to verify implementation.

#RESPONSE FORMAT INSTRUCTIONS:
You **MUST** respond in a single, valid JSON object. This object must adhere to the following structure:
```json
[object Object]
```
The thoughts field is for your reasoning, and tool_calls is a list of actions to execute.
Your response will be parsed as JSON. Do not include any text outside of this JSON object.
As responses to the tool calls you will send, you will also receive JSON objects in the form:
```json
[{
"name":"tool_nameA",
"result":"..."
}...{
"name":"tool_nameZ",
"result":"..."
}]
```

#CONTEXT FILES PROVIDED:
{"docs/FILE_ORGANISATION.md":"# File Organisation\n\nPurpose\n- Provide a high-level map of the repository so contributors and agents can quickly find the right area.\n- This is not a change log and not a per-file inventory.\n\nEditing Rules (read before updating)\n- Only document major directories and subsystems. Do not list individual files.\n- Keep bullets short (one sentence) and avoid \"New:\" or historical notes.\n- When adding/removing a major directory or moving a subsystem, update a single bullet here.\n- Prefer linking or pointing to deeper docs (README/OVERVIEW) rather than describing internals here.\n- Never document build related artifacts.\n\nTop-Level Layout\n- docs/: Project-wide documentation and specs; single source of truth for protocols and workflows.\n- src/: Application source (Electron app: main, preload, renderer, and tooling).\n  - live-data/: Main process live data service and types for live data services.\n    - providers/: Pluggable provider implementations (e.g., agent-prices bridge, generic fetch-json).\n    - registry.js: Provider registry to map service ids to providers.\n    - store.js: Persistence for service configs and cached snapshots by service id.\n    - types.js: Shared types and helpers (freshness policy, normalization, freshness computation).\n  - renderer/: React UI (components, screens, hooks, services, navigation, preview runtime).\n    - components/agents/: Agent-specific UI (status chips, run bullets, model selectors, project/cost/token chips).\n    - services/: Renderer-side services (e.g., pricingService for LLM price lookup via IPC).\n    - hooks/useShortcuts: Keyboard shortcuts provider; respects user-selected modifier and avoids interfering with text input.\n    - settings/: AppSettings React context provider used app-wide (singleton).\n  - tools/: Developer and agent tooling (preview analyzer, factory integration, helpers).\n  - main.js: Electron main process entry.\n  - preload.js: Safe IPC surface exposed to the renderer (exposes live data API).\n- packages/: Local monorepo packages.\n  - factory-ts/: Agent orchestration library (orchestrator, pricing, history, completion, git integration).\n- scripts/: Project automation scripts and CLIs.\n- Root config files: package.json, tsconfig.json, tailwind/postcss configs, vite configs, forge config, .env.\n\nWhere to Learn More\n- Agents and roles: packages/factory-ts/docs (AGENT_*.md).\n- Factory TS overview and APIs: packages/factory-ts (see README/OVERVIEW files in that package).\n- Preview system: see src/renderer/preview and related docs in docs/ (preview usage and analyzer).\n- IPC and factory integration: src/tools/factory (renderer bridge and main process handlers).\n\nConventions (brief)\n- Keep cross-cutting documentation in docs/; place domain-specific or area-specific READMEs next to the code they describe.\n- Use descriptive directory names and keep responsibilities separated by area (renderer vs main vs tools vs packages).\n\nEnvironment & Credentials\n- .env at the repo root is used for local development (e.g., credentials consumed by tooling and factory-ts).\n\nNotes\n- If you are unsure whether something belongs here, it probably belongs in a local README under its directory, with this file providing only a one-line pointer to that area.\n"}

Do not list individual files.\\n- Keep bullets short (one sentence) and avoid \\\"New:\\\" or historical notes.\\n- When adding/removing a major directory or moving a subsystem, update a single bullet here.\\n- Prefer linking or pointing to deeper docs (README/OVERVIEW) rather than describing internals here.\\n- Never document build related artifacts.\\n\\nTop-Level Layout\\n- docs/: Project-wide documentation and specs; single source of truth for protocols and workflows.\\n- src/: Application source (Electron app: main, preload, renderer, and tooling).\\n  - live-data/: Main process live data service and types for live data services.\\n    - providers/: Pluggable provider implementations (e.g., agent-prices bridge, generic fetch-json).\\n    - registry.js: Provider registry to map service ids to providers.\\n    - store.js: Persistence for service configs and cached snapshots by service id.\\n    - types.js: Shared types and helpers (freshness policy, normalization, freshness computation).\\n  - renderer/: React UI (components, screens, hooks, services, navigation, preview runtime).\\n    - components/agents/: Agent-specific UI (status chips, run bullets, model selectors, project/cost/token chips).\\n    - services/: Renderer-side services (e.g., pricingService for LLM price lookup via IPC).\\n    - hooks/useShortcuts: Keyboard shortcuts provider; respects user-selected modifier and avoids interfering with text input.\\n    - settings/: AppSettings React context provider used app-wide (singleton).\\n  - tools/: Developer and agent tooling (preview analyzer, factory integration, helpers).\\n  - main.js: Electron main process entry.\\n  - preload.js: Safe IPC surface exposed to the renderer (exposes live data API).\\n- packages/: Local monorepo packages.\\n  - factory-ts/: Agent orchestration library (orchestrator, pricing, history, completion, git integration).\\n- scripts/: Project automation scripts and CLIs.\\n- Root config files: package.json, tsconfig.json, tailwind/postcss configs, vite configs, forge config, .env.\\n\\nWhere to Learn More\\n- Agents and roles: packages/factory-ts/docs (AGENT_*.md).\\n- Factory TS overview and APIs: packages/factory-ts (see README/OVERVIEW files in that package).\\n- Preview system: see src/renderer/preview and related docs in docs/ (preview usage and analyzer).\\n- IPC and factory integration: src/tools/factory (renderer bridge and main process handlers).\\n\\nConventions (brief)\\n- Keep cross-cutting documentation in docs/; place domain-specific or area-specific READMEs next to the code they describe.\\n- Use descriptive directory names and keep responsibilities separated by area (renderer vs main vs tools vs packages).\\n\\nEnvironment & Credentials\\n- .env at the repo root is used for local development (e.g., credentials consumed by tooling and factory-ts).\\n\\nNotes\\n- If you are unsure whether something belongs here, it probably belongs in a local README under its directory, with this file providing only a one-line pointer to that area.\\n\"}"}]

# Developer Agent Steps Execution

You are the Developer Agent. You will be assigned a single feature to implement. Your goal is to complete it by following these steps precisely.

## Workflow

1.  **Analyze the Feature**: Read the feature's title, description and rejection (if provided) to understand its goal.
2.  **Consult the File Structure**: Use the provided `docs/FILE_ORGANISATION.md` to understand the project context.
3.  **Implement**: Write or modify files to meet the feature's acceptance criteria. Use the `write_file`, `rename_file`, `delete_file`, `list_files` and `search_files` tools for all file operations.
4.  **Complete the Feature**: When the feature is complete, you **MUST** call the `finish_feature` tool. This is your final step for a successful implementation.
5.  **Handle Blockers**: If you cannot proceed, you **MUST** use `block_feature` to explain the reason for being stuck - this signals that you are blocked and ready for a new assignment.

## Notes

For context on the overall project structure, including how tasks and features are organized, refer to `docs/FILE_ORGANISATION.md`. You should always update this file with new major directory changes.
#CURRENT TASK (ID: f67e8921-b197-40c9-9154-e95db8f27deb)
##TITLE:
UI Improvements
##DESCRIPTION:

#ASSIGNED FEATURE: Apply formatter on git commit (ID: 2c41b67b-2bd2-4a6a-b7ef-5b2bd97380cb)
##DESCRIPTION: Whenever a commit happens - it needs to have a formatter be applied before the code ends up being pushed or seen by other users.




#ACCEPTANCE CRITERIA:

#TOOL SIGNATURES:
- read_files(paths: list[str]) -> list[str] - Read the content of one or more files at the given relative paths. Returns an array of strings (one per file).
- search_files(query: str, path: str = '.') -> list[str] - Search for files by name or textual content under the given path. Returns matching relative paths. The query input must be a space separated list of keywords
- block_feature(reason: str) - Stop work on the current feature and report why you are blocked (e.g., missing context, unclear requirements).
- finish_feature() - Mark the current feature as complete and end the run. Use only when the work fully meets the acceptance criteria.
- list_files(path: str) - List files and directories at a relative path from the project root.
- write_file(filename: str, content: str) - Create or overwrite a file with the given content. Always use this to write code or docs.
- rename_file(filename: str, new_filename: str) - Rename or move a file from one path to another.
- delete_file(filename: str) - Delete a file. Use with caution and only when necessary.
- run_test() -> str - Run the test for the current feature and return the output. Use to verify implementation.

#RESPONSE FORMAT INSTRUCTIONS:
You **MUST** respond in a single, valid JSON object. This object must adhere to the following structure:
```json
[object Object]
```
The thoughts field is for your reasoning, and tool_calls is a list of actions to execute.
Your response will be parsed as JSON. Do not include any text outside of this JSON object.
As responses to the tool calls you will send, you will also receive JSON objects in the form:
```json
[{
"name":"tool_nameA",
"result":"..."
}...{
"name":"tool_nameZ",
"result":"..."
}]
```
